
[TITLE]
<line: 2> IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
<line: 3> FOR THE DISTRICT OF PUERTO RICO 

[TABLE]
<line: 5> UNITED STATES OF AMERICA    *   CRIMINAL NO.17-00080 (PG) 
<line: 6> Plaintiff                   *                             
<line: 7>                             *                                              
<line: 8> v.                          * 
<line: 9>                             * 
<line: 10> JOSE LUIS RODRIGUEZ NUNEZ   *   
<line: 11> Defendant________________   * 

[TITLE]
<line: 13> SENTENCING MEMORANDUM 

[TEXT]
<line: 15> TO THE HONORABLE JUDGE PEREZ GIMENEZ: 

[TEXT]
<line: 17>    COMES NOW, Mr. JOSE LUIS RODRIGUEZ NUNEZ through the undersigned 
<line: 18> attorney, and respectfully states and prays as follows: 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> 1. There are no objections to the Presentence Report.  

[TEXT]
<line: 22> 2.  The corresponding Presentence Report was prepared and notified 
<line: 23> to the undersigned attorney. Such report was discussed with Jose 
<line: 24> Luis Rodriguez.  

[TEXT]
<line: 26> 3. There is no Plea Agreement in this case, but the parties stated 
<line: 27> for the record at the Change of Plea Hearing that a recommendation 
<line: 28> of time served is sufficient but not greater than necessary. 

[TITLE]
<line: 30> II. Mr. Rodriguez Nuñez Personal Characteristics: 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> 4. Mr. Rodriguez Nuñez is a humble construction worker and 
<line: 33> fisherman from Samana, Dominican Republic. 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> 5. Was raised in a very poor neighborhood and household in Samana, 
<line: 3> where he had to quit school in 5Th grade to work in Agriculture 
<line: 4> with his dad due to the fact that he has 12 siblings and his 
<line: 5> parents needed the economic support to bring food to the table. 
<line: 6> 6. He is a father of 4 children. All of them live at the Dominican 
<line: 7> Republic with their respective mothers. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> 7. He has no history of the use of alcohol and controlled 
<line: 10> substances. 

[TITLE]
<line: 12> III. Circumstances of the offense 

[TEXT]
<line: 14>  Mr. Rodriguez Nuñez embarked in Dominican Republic to Puerto 
<line: 15> Rico fleeing from his country due to the fact that a nephew killed 
<line: 16> his sister’s husband and his ex-brother in laws family threated to 
<line: 17> kill him. All this information was provided to Border Patrol Agent 
<line: 18> Loskar Luhring after his arrest. 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> His sister, Jackeline Rodriguez Nuñez, filed an application 
<line: 21> for Asylum and for Withholding of Removal in this District for the 
<line: 22> reasons mentioned above.  

[TITLE]
<line: 24> IV. Procedural Background 

[TEXT]
<line: 26> Mr. Rodriguez Nuñez was arrested on January 23, 2017 and has 
<line: 27> been detained since at MDC Guaynabo. He was indicted in February 
<line: 28> 9, 2017 in violation of 8 U.S.C. section 1326 (a)(1) & 2. He made 
<line: 29> a straight plea on April 19, 2017. An expedite Presentence Report 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> was filed on April 25, 2017 and today we have reviewed it with Mr. 
<line: 3> Rodriguez Nuñez at MDC in the Spanish Language. 

[TITLE]
<line: 5> V. Sentencing  

[TEXT]
<line: 7> In United States v. Booker, 543 U.S. 245 (2005), the United 
<line: 8> States Supreme Court restored to Sentencing Judges the power to 
<line: 9> use their discretion in determining the appropriate sentence.  Id. 
<line: 10> See also Gall v. United States, 552 U.S. 38 (2007); jointly with 
<line: 11> the arguments as to the proper sentence in each particular case 
<line: 12> “weighing the applicability of the sundry factors delineated in 18 
<line: 13> U.S.C. section 3553. United States v. Martin, 520 F.3d 91; citing 
<line: 14> Gall v. United States, 522 U.S. 50. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> According to the factors 18 USCA sec. 1553(a,” the court shall 
<line: 17> impose a sentence sufficient, but not greater than necessary,” to 
<line: 18> reflect the seriousness of the of the offense, to promote respect 
<line: 19> for the law, and to provide just punishment for the offense; afford 
<line: 20> adequate deterrence to criminal conduct; protect the public from 
<line: 21> further crimes of the defendant; and to provide the defendant with 
<line: 22> needed educational or vocational training, medical care or other 
<line: 23> correctional treatment in the most effective manner.” Id.; 
<line: 24> Kimbrough v. United States, 552 US 85, 101 (2007). 

[TEXT]
<line: 26> The Sentencing determination in this case shall begin with 
<line: 27> the correct calculation of the particular’s defendant’s guideline. 
<line: 28> According to the Sentencing Guidelines Manual, the violation for 
<line: 29> the attempt to re-enter of a Removed Alien. The Base Offense level 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> is 8 as provided in section (a) of USSG 2L1.2. There are no 
<line: 3> enhancements found. For Acceptance of responsibility according to 
<line: 4> USSG section 3E1.1 a reduction of 2 levels applies. This results 
<line: 5> in a level offense level of 6. According to the Presentence report, 
<line: 6> Mr. Rodriguez Nuñez has a Criminal History of 1. This results in 
<line: 7> a Sentencing Guideline range of 0-6 months. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> If The Court’s agree with our sentencing guidelines 
<line: 10> calculation and the recommendation of the parties, a time served 
<line: 11> sentence shall be imposed. Also The Court should take into account 
<line: 12> the nature and circumstances of the offense and the reasons behing 
<line: 13> it. 

[TEXT]
<line: 15> WHEREFORE, for the reasons above stated, it is respectfully 
<line: 16> requested from this Honorable Court sentence Mr. Rodriguez Nuñez 
<line: 17> to the Recommended Sentence agreed by the parties of time served.  
<line: 18> In San Juan, Puerto Rico, April 27, 2017.  

[TITLE]
<line: 20>                               S/ EDUARDO FERRER RIOS
